The "Robocop" remake lacks originality. While this Robo-remake was slightly better than most remakes it still lacked something that only the original had.    

Every so often Hollywood gets the bright idea to remake classic or original films that should be left alone. Now, don't get me wrong, there have been some remakes in the past that have made a significant improvement from the original. Remakes like: The Fly (1986), 3:10 to Yuma (2007), King Kong (2005), Scarface (1983), Cape Fear (1991) and Oceans Eleven (2001) all stood out from the original. But when there are good remakes, there come bad ones as well. Remakes like: Clash of the Titans (2010), Conan the Barbarian (2011), The Day the Earth Stood Still (2008), Halloween (2007), The Invasion (2007), Planet of the Apes (2001) and Psycho (1998) all were awful remakes and films in general. Back to my point, while Jose Padilha's (Elite Squad) Robo-remake was much better than any of these bad remakes in my opinion, it still did not make a significant improvement over Paul Verhoeven's 1987 original. 

The original Robocop was no masterpiece by any means, but it still had that special something from the '80s. Verhoeven packed in themes of gentrification, corruption, authoritarianism, capitalism, revenge, dystopia and ultra-violence. These aspects are what made that film so unique from that time period. The year is 2028, and OmniCorp is at the center of their "robot soldier" technology, when Alex Murphy, (Joel Kinnaman) - a good father and cop in the corrupted Detroit - is critically injured in a car bomb. OmniCorp makes their golden opportunity to create their Robocop, turning Murphy into part man, and mostly part machine. Kinnaman did an OK  job as Robocop, but I preferred Peter Weller's performance from the original. Director Padilha lacked Verhoeven's craft and critical/comical satire in the film. The next flaw was the PG-13 rating. This of course was made to boost ticket sales for younger audiences, but the ultra-violence is what made the original stand out. The ultra-violence was a major factor for the original because Verhoeven used it to satire the American culture. 

While the special effects were a huge improvement from the original, it still should not be the biggest factor for a film. One noble performance from the film that I should point out was Gary Oldman. He plays scientist Dr. Dennett Norton and does a superb job. Oldman has always been an actor I have admired, so if you do go see this film, go see it for his performance alone. Another thing this film did a decent job on was focusing more on Murphy's family relationship after he turns into Robocop. Sadly, half way through the film the ending became predictable and was totally bland from there on. 

Overall, this Robocop had some entertaining aspects (special effects and Oldman's performance), but it also contained negative feedback for the lack of direction, absence of Peter Weller, lack of ultra-violence, the predictable ending and the lack of making it stand out from the original.

When reviewing any remake, it can be a challenge to stay objective. Especially when you personally hold the original in high regard. Being a child of the 80's, Peter Weller will always be the definitive Robocop of my childhood (hows that for being objective?) and there lays the first problem, There are a lot of original robo fans out there who have been waiting patiently to see another outing with their favourite cyborg cop. However after the anticlimactic débâcle that is Robocop3, it is understandable why some fans would rather the franchise be left alone. That is unless by some freak turn of events, Weller now 66, reprised the role with Paul Verhoeven back in the director's chair. Sadly that simply isn't on the cards, leaving us to settle for the next best thing, a reboot. The new movie retells the story of Alex Murphy from a very different angle to that of the original 80`s movie. José Padilhait should be praised for daring to branch out from the established story and breathing air in to the franchise. However setting a PG13 rating, I have to wonder if he ever actually saw the original. Hollywood seems to believe movies today need to meet the 13-17 demographic to stand any chance of making money. Personally I'm inclined to say the reboot suffered due this decision. Robocop and the characters that populate Verhoeven's dystopian future can only truly work in an adult rated movie. Padilhait's Detroit lacks any of the social decay or gritty run down appearance of the original. In fact it actually looks pretty clean, which left me wondering why they needed Robocop in the first place. Not a single one of the villains was really intimidating on screen. The worst still was realising who the main villain was, something that didn't happened until very late in the movie, by which time it felt like a rushed after thought. 
Perhaps this is a fault of a PG13, which takes the edge off otherwise dark characters, preventing them from being who they could or should be. Robocop spends a lot of the movie struggling with his emotions, when really he should be out cleaning up the city. Oh wait that's right the city wasn't that dirty to begin with, why do we need Robocop again?
How any of the family orientated fluff is important to a teenage audience is beyond me. As a teen, I watched Robocop for the brutality, the gore and to see a cyborg cop kicking butt and lets not forget how Robo deals with rapist! 
While the reboot does bring a fresh perspective to the Alex Murphy story arch, the most important side, the action was seriously lacking. What is so good about Robocop taking out bad guys in the dark? And why was it necessary to explain his every action with techno babble? What made the original work so well was its lack of explanation, leaving the audience to fill in the gaps for themselves. The reboot doesn't settle for showing us Robocop, it insists on explaining how the magic trick works and in the process spoiling the illusion.

If you want an action movie you could do worse then Robocop, however there are other PG13 movies, which offer better action and darker villains. In fact if you're an adult, just watch the original Robocop, aged it might have, but the story still beats this hands down.

But that mechanical feel is well interspersed with human moments that develop Robocop Alex Murphy's struggles to accept his new role in life. The moments where his past memories intersect with his programming are well played by  Alex Murphy (Joel Kinnaman). Simultaneously Robocop deals with modern questions about how many concessions Americans will make to ensure their own security, and examines whether drones should be carrying out the actions they do abroad today. At one point the film clearly states that safety is not freedom, and that indeed too much safety might equal less freedom. Special effects are well done and the CGI movements of the robots are completely believable. Perhaps because such things are not really science fiction anymore but basically reality.

But once it's over and everything has sunk in, it feels kind of pointless, because the original is stuck with you.  Joel Kinneman steps in as the half robot/half cop, and he does fantastic.  I'm a huge fan of his from "The Killing", and he does great.  As does Michael Keaton, Jackie Earle Haley, and Gary Oldman.  This movie has a terrific cast.  Samuel L Jackson has a small role as a political talk show host, that could have been bigger and meant more.  But it doesn't bring anything new to the franchise or take it to another level.  It is exactly what the original was, a B+ action movie with some subtext.  Maybe if it was rated R like the original and could have gone harder, it would have been better.  I mean, it's not that it's a bad movie, but it isn't.  It's just in 5 years when you want to watch "Robocop", you will always choose the original over this, and in 15 years this will be forgotten. One of the greatest disappointments of my adult life. How shitty is this reboot? Let me count the ways (Spoilers!). First off, PG-13 rating (WTF were they thinking?)They made the Auto-9 non-lethal. No psychotic drug kingpins. Barely gave ED-209 a cameo. Nobody got shot in the dick, I mean shit, hardly anybody got shot at all - other than with tasers (boooo!). Now, I know some will say, "Oh, but what about the 50 cal. T-Rex submachine gun?" Yeah, well that's fuckin' cool, but the only thing he ever shoots with it are the damn robots. I don't think they even used a single squib in the remake, which is just an insult to a franchise that (up until now) made use of more squibs than can even be counted reliably.  

In the original, Murphy retains at least some of his body, requiring him to eat (remember the Gerber's?). In this acid-trip-alternative universe where CGI is always best, he's reduced to nothing but a talking head and lungs! Seriously WTF? And why even with the lungs if they have that kind of technology? His entire fucking body, save the head, eyeballs and one hand (and, conveniently I guess, his cardiopulmonary system) is gone, and you're gonna tell me that they can't find a better way to oxygenate then without relying on his frail, infection-prone human lungs? That would mean Robocop is effectively immune to almost all kinds of small arms fire, but fucking tear gas or bronchitis could fuck up his day! 

Ok, now let's explore the "plot." Murphy dealing with being a man trapped in a machine, trying to wrestle the memories of his family out of his programming took like 3 scenes and 20 min of the original, with the rest of the movie being a gore fest. In this new version, that struggle with his mind/OCP programming was ALL there was. Seriously, the main fucking bad guy in this movie was the OCP programming, which Murphy overcomes with his willpower.

And then there is the terrible social commentary, which if it wasn't already blatantly obvious (armed drones in USA = bad idea), is made patently clear by Sam Jackson's over-the-top caricature of a big-media political puppet with an obvious (and, of course, implied paid-for) stake in the "drones are good" camp.

And who is to blame for this tragedy? Ultimately, Sony and MGM, for pulling a turnabout and replacing the combination of Aronofsky/Self with Padilha/Zetumer. First of all, this was Padilha's first film using the English language, and Zetumer is a virtual unknown. I know James Vanderbilt supposedly contributed, but with credits like White House Down and The Amazing Spiderman 2 to his name, that aint saying much. In the end, it comes down to terrible writing, an over-reliance on special effects to make it more impressive in 3D, and the inability of a fledgling director to recognize that he was creating the film equivalent of human excrement.

Let me say that I was a fan of the first two Robocop movies as a kid, and grew up hating the 3rd, and never got into the comics or the cartoons. But over time the bad special fx, and camp factor of the first two movies are obvious as they don't hold up very well today.

It's a very cool storyline tho one which can easily be translated to what we are facing today with invasion of privacy, and the potential of us losing some of the freedoms we have due to political unrest.

Robocop much like the Terminator series, and even the Matrix trilogy reminds us that our evolution as human beings could easily be in danger if we aren't careful with our own creations. While we like to think we are very smart, and we like to play god sometimes it begs the question when have we gone too far?

The film takes place in the year 2028 so it's not that far fetched to think that this could happen one day soon when we look at how advanced computers are today. We are not looking at something that far off in the future here at all.

Now this remake has managed to anger a lot of fanboys online from day one people complained, and nit picked at little things which made no sense really. Most complained because they said the movie having a black suit looked too much like something out of BATMAN. Ironically enough Michael Keaton is in the movie, and he played Batman. Keaton plays Raymond Sellars the CEO of OmniCorp or OCP for short. Yes they kept OCP as the company name.

When multinational conglomerate OmniCorp who is at the center of robot technology, and is in charge of taking care of our global wars using their robots overseas, their drones have been used by the military for years - and it's meant billions for OmniCorp's bottom line. Now OmniCorp wants to bring their controversial technology to the home front, and they see a golden opportunity to do it.

When Alex Murphy (Joel Kinnaman) - a loving husband, father and good cop doing his best to stem the tide of crime and corruption in Detroit - is critically injured in the line of duty, OmniCorp sees their chance for a part-man, part-robot police officer. OmniCorp envisions a RoboCop in every city and even more billions for their shareholders, but they never counted on one thing: there is still a man inside the machine pursuing justice.

The movie has one of the best cast I've seen put together for a remake ever. Besides Michael Keaton, and Joel Kinnaman the film also has fellow Batman alumni Gary Oldman as Dr. Dennett Norton the Doctor Frankenstein of the movie. He's the man behind the machine, and the real brains behind OCP.

Jackie Earle Haley as Rick Mattox the man who's in charge of training Robocop, and eventually has to try, and stop him.

Jay Baruchel as Tom Pope who's fresh of his big hit film "This is the END" he plays one of the marketing geniuses at OCP who's trying to figure out the best way to sell a "Robocop" to the people.

Abbie Cornish as Clara Murphy is a bit under used in the film but it's not shocking when they have so much story to tell. Either way she was excellent in her performance, and what I loved the most about this movie is the strong bond between the Murphy family, and that is evident by the good chemistry that Joel & Abbie had on screen.

The movie also has Sam Jackson in a political tv show type who only comes out in scenes promoting the OCP agenda. Don't want to give too much away but he's a scene stealer, and at the very start of the movie he does just that. But it's not shocking Sam Jackson always steals the scenes he's in. He's that great of an actor. Michael Keaton also does a fantastic job here looking sympathetic one minute, and evil the next. He steals a bunch of scenes here also, and gave a great performance.

There is one scene when Dr. Dennett Norton shows Murphy what is actually left of his body, and he takes him apart. This is a very powerful scene, and acted very well by both men. Remember Murphy loses his limbs, and all that's left here after they put him in the suit is his head, a hand, and lungs.

People ask why would they keep one of his hands? Well I think it's to allow him to have "feel" when he touches something. But that isn't really addressed in the movie. But I think it's a way to allow him to keep a little piece of his humanity.

Honestly overall everyone was great in this movie, and even tho fanboys also complained about the PG-13 rating this movie has a bigger body count, and more action then the original. So reason why Murphy gets to become the chosen one for Robocop is a bit under developed but it's tied up very well at the end.

IF there isn't a sequel to this movie it's tied up well enough that it would work as a stand alone movie. But I do hope to see a sequel to it. I really think it deserved better, and the fans who have hated on it for no other reason other than to hate because it's not exactly how the original was I say this.

You want something that's a shot for shot remake? Look at Psycho, and how that turned out. They have a lot of nods to the original movie here we even get a nice reference to "I'd buy that for a dollar!" I think people just have a problem sometimes letting go, and they can't accept updates to classic movies.

But if you go into this movie with an open mind, and are willing to give it a fair chance you will be surprised about how good it actually is.

José Padilha is a great up, and coming film maker, and sadly the studio was a bit hard for him to work with, and while this movie is really good had he been given full creative control we could have had a masterpiece.

That this isn't but honestly it's a worthy remake to a classic, and it's a movie that deserves a better fate than it looks like it's going to get, and which at times is actually a better film then the original. The human element works much better here then it ever did in the original.

Padilha's RoboCop starring Joel Kinnaman, if we are to evaluate it with a view to the original, might have been a pretty creative retread. Though both films seem to turn on the same themes, those being techno-liberal justice and the critique of neoliberal policing that persists today, Padilha's version makes an attempt at creating a sleeker version by dealing a renewed dose of science fictional estrangement in the beginning. Trying to be relevant, the film begins with a critique of international policing that forces us to examine our present, a time of globalization, reborn 'zero tolerance,' privatized soldiers, remote drone attacks, and political polarization over issues of national security. It fails, however, to pick up this compelling international thread after the first 15 minutes. As a dystopia that globalizes the original's satire of neoliberalism, this film could have been headier and something completely different from its 1987 predecessor. 

Verhoeven's original was a clever and entertaining critique that ultimately championed a facile techno-liberal solution to the problems of street crime. Indeed, Alex Murphy in Verhoeven's version, though capable of human discretion and emotion, was nothing more than a superhuman, galvanized urban Rambo out for revenge. It is hardly relevant that revenge is a particularly human foible. Though the film looked interesting in the beginning, it pretty much ended up valorizing the same facile, testosterone-charged solution to crime and, just as the original, unsubtly makes the heterosexual family the anchor for human sentiment and the exception to the dehumanizing effects of technological evolution. It is certainly not the first or last work of art that that will commit that crime. Nonetheless, perhaps it's because I had less attachment to the original -- I was only about 6 when  Paul Verhoeven's RoboCop hit theaters -- I didn't mind the recent reincarnation. That doesn't mean I liked it though.

A decent film that tries to be more than an action movie, but is only partially successful. 

The original RoboCop is one my favourite films of all time, and has established some particularly memorable moments and characters in film history. 

This remake doesn't attempt to re-tell the exact same themes of consumerism and privatisation as the original. Instead, it addresses other themes of security, surveillance and control, which is probably a wise move.

In the past, I would normally have made the suggestion that a film like this might be better off not using the name of a beloved original, and tried to be its own original film. This was certainly the case with the Total Recall remake. However, in this case, if the film had attempted that, it's likely that the film would still be interpreted as a "RoboCop wannabe". If a filmmaker is going to remake RoboCop, this is as good an attempt as any.

Ultimately it's quite enjoyable, but its biggest problem is that it's missing the X-Factor of iconic moments and characters. Moments like when ED-209 malfunctions the first time when it's introduced, or the TV ads used in the original. There aren't those moments in the remake, and that may reflect the difference between a good director and a great director. 

This means that this film is quite good, but will probably end up as a footnote rather than a landmark in film history.

Why would you even want to make a PG-13 RoboCop?  Alex Murphy (Joel Kinnaman) is a cop that is crippled in a traumatic explosion, but they can make him harder, better, faster and stronger, so they meld man to machine to make RoboCop.  The original RoboCop had the tremendous benefit of being directed Paul Verhoeven, who knows how to work social commentary into a science-fiction story.  He can take an idea that is ludicrous on paper (seriously, the conceit of a robot cop is pretty juvenile when you stop and think about it), and make it completely cerebral and relevant.  I will give you this: the special effects here are good looking, and it is pretty cool to see a disassembled RoboCop body, but that is the only thing that this remake has a leg up on the original.  If you didn't have a new or fresh spin to take on the story, why would you even bother to do it in the first place?  The original really overachieved when you get right down to it, and this completely neuters and sterilizes the story to make it a completely generic action movie that has no tooth.  I don't blame the actors here, as there is effort being placed forth.  Gary Oldman doesn't just phone it in, and Samuel Jackson chews scenery, although I will say that Kinnaman is a bit bland as the RoboCop, and has nothing on Peter Weller.  This isn't the worst thing you could watch, but much like the Total Recall remake, there really is no wow-factor, and it is an action movie that is ultimately forgettable.

It is important to note that I have not watched the original RoboCop and I heard many people claim that rebooting it is stupid as the concept is no longer relevant. I can't tell how close the new film is to its source material, but, to my surprise, it was not only relevant, but also a good movie in general. That said, it did come with quite a few flaws of varying importance.

RoboCop is mostly a satire on mainstream American media and their effect on public opinion and governmental decisions. While it also touches on the way the United States treats countries abroad, specifically in and around the Middle-East, the idea is not explored beyond the premise of the movie. The way it approaches its critique of media is both through humour and drama, which seems frivolous, but still appropriate in tone. The way some news channels shamelessly and nonapologetically expose their biases and political agenda is, for all intents and purposes, inappropriate. It makes for a poorly informed society, and seeing a film pick up on that, make fun of it, and shed light on its potential consequences is essential.

Unfortunately, there are a few themes RoboCop could have delved into much deeper than it ultimately did. One in particular is the question it implicitly asks many times over: "What makes us human?" It seems that the movie tries to base most of its explanations on pseudoscience and the ethics that come along with it; however, at one point, the protagonist manages to override Dr. Norton's tweaks to his brain and, this being a very climactic moment, an opportunity the filmmakers could seize to answer the question, it simply goes to waste. One character eventually vaguely mentions the existence of a "soul" in a sarcastic tone, but the idea isn't explored much beyond that. A possible route the film could have taken would be to address the mysteriousness of science, and to show that no matter how advanced our technology, there will always be seemingly inexplicable phenomena just waiting to be explored. Otherwise, they could have gone completely against such a world view. Instead, they remained passive and the question was never answered or brought up again: it ended up being a banal vehicle to make the plot progress forward.

Speaking of plot progression, there are many illogical, let alone absurd story elements designed to transition from one scene to another that could have been handled much more smoothly. For example, just before Murphy's reveal to the public as RoboCop, the authorities decided it would be a good time to upload the entire criminal record database to his brain in a few seconds which resulted in an unsurprising panic attack and made them take drastic measures as an attempt to fix the problem. The decision is clearly too silly to be real and takes the viewer straight out of the experience. Another pointless addition to the film is Rick Mattox's character. He is an asshole for the sake of being one and adds little to nothing to the whole movie. Although few characters feel real, this one shines in his two-dimensionality. He is the archetype of the flat character: he doesn't evolve one bit and adds zero comedy or drama to the movie. He is but a tool.

The characters could have been written better, but Gary Oldman, Michael Keaton, and, to a certain extent, Samuel L. Jackson really bring their characters to life with solid performances that overshadow the mediocre dialogue.

Visually, the film looks dated. There are a few technical missteps in the special effects, but the reason it's unappealing is because of its blandness. The choreographers didn't reinvent the wheel, they just created a spinning tin man wielding two guns, an oddly common practice, except for the tin man part. Some shootouts are enjoyable, but they certainly are not the highlights of the film.

In retrospect, RoboCop is a good relevant movie that's worth a watch despite its many faults, but I don't see it becoming a classic. I don't know how good the first one was, but surely it had something more substantial going on for it.

A reboot of a legendary action-flick, Robocop is a well-made, nicely polished and dark, modernized version of its predecessor. While far from being close to achieving the cult status of the original movie, this is a very good and decently entertaining action with a story relevant to a future that seems more and more probable. 

Again set in Detroit and once again with the high-tech corporation OmniCorp in the center of the story, director Jose Padilha does his best to keep the movie the closest possible to the original. The background of the story is changed, as this time OmniCorp is not really fighting the crime in Detroit, but searching for a way to sell its robots on US soil, rather than only overseas. When Officer Alex Murphy is ambushed and almost killed, OmniCorps grasps its chance to create Robocop. The reboot certainly lacks the fun element which made the 1987 delivery a cult, but on the other side it is cynic and sharp enough when it comes to describing politics, media influences and corporate world. 

Jose Padilha's version is also more human and Alex Murphy/Robocop (Joel Kinnaman) is still connected to his loving family. This leaves less screen time for a development of "the bad guys", but on the other hand Murphy's character becomes more complex, more dramatic and less detached from the human reality. In terms of acting and cast, Joel Kinnaman could not match the level of Peter Weller, but on the positive side it is a nice surprise to see Michael Keaten in the role of the corporate mogul Raymond Sellars.

In the end, the 2014 Robocop will never become as memorable and legendary as the original 1987 movie, but it will be remembered as a decently entertaining sci-fi action flick. With its budget of $100 mio.,only $60 mio. domestic and $185 mio. international box office, the possibility of establishing a new franchise seems to be very small unless it performs excellently on the home video market. Better than expected, Robocop surely deserves at least a new sequel.

Brazilian director Jose Padilha gets his American debut with the start-studded remake of RoboCop.  This Hollywood popcorn flick is best enjoyed by not comparing it to Verhoeven's satire riddled, religious iconography packed, hyper-violent with a borderline X-rated, cult classic original.  Padilha's RoboCop is exactly what you'd expect from any other cookie cutter project that some studio big shot thought would be a good investment, but the director actually holds his own, conforming to a PG-13 rating without sacrificing too much in the way of storyline, or action.  
  
The story is straight forward, and serves mainly as a vehicle to get RoboCop from point to point so he can shoot stuff.  If you're looking for a robot cop walking around and shooting other robots, gang members, corrupt cops, big business CEO's and bigger robots for an hour or so, then this is your ticket to RoboParadise.  The pace is quick, and the film hardly ever drags, which is important for the popcorn demographic this movie seems to be aimed at.

The cast is well implemented, featuring veteran actors like Time Burton's Bruce Wayne, a Bill O'Reilly channeling Samuel Motherfuckin Jackson, the always brilliant Gary Oldman and lovable newcomers like Jay "guy with a maple leaf tattoo" Baruschel and Omar who now works with the police force as a SWAT sergeant.  

Music was pretty unimpressive.  Standard Hollywood fare big orchestra compositions, with no distinctive or unique sound.  The cinematography was consistently solid, but nothing I would particularly go out of my way to call unique either.  The HUD views from the POV shots of RoboCop were well developed and immersive, but best of all, the displays and readouts all seemed to have a real purpose rather than being composed of frivolous after effects porn.

Overall, give it a watch if you want some brainless action.  With luck, this film could get Padilha enough credibility to direct another Hollywood backed film, but with some more creative control at hand.

On his own terms, which forego the original 1987 movie's hyper-violence, plot, and much of it's satirical edge, director Jose Padilha entertainingly combines big ideas with slick, dazzling action, while Joshua Zetumer's screenplay does a rather satisfactory job at exploring the ethics - and politics - of having a private corporation (OCP) create a half-man half-robot crime fighter outside the scope of the law. Good casting: Joel Kinnaman's Alex Murphy / Robocop is sympathetic and surprisingly human; strongly supported by Gary Oldman, ideally cast as the doctor tasked with Murphy's transformation. Oldman's character's constant struggle to balance ethics and Murphy's family's concerns with the requirements of OCP and it's CEO (Michael Keaton, in a very entertaining performance that proves you don't need to chew scenery to be the baddie), actually makes his interaction with Murphy one of the most interesting features of the story. Jay Baruchel as a weaselly marketing man, and Jackie Earl Haley as a gruff weapons trainer are also entertaining; not so Samuel L Jackson, cast as a fascist news presenter as part of the film's failed attempt to include some of the augmented satire that characterized the original. Here, it comes off flat. Fortunately, it does not break the movie, which against expectation, does not end up feeling like a cynical money grabbing attempt from its studio (it may well be), and although one can argue remakes are indicative of a bankrupt imagination, this film proves that the premise of Robocop was worthy of an update in the era of drones and smartphones.

Robocop is a remake of the much-too-similar 1987 film of the same name that starred Peter Weller in the title role.  This time around Joel Kinnaman ('The Killing') steps into the suit of the robotic policeman/piece of weaponry created to fight crime on the streets of Detroit.  The film ventures into the territory of corporate greed and had a chance to become rather relevant; but it never really decides to tackle a whole lot by never going too deeply into a story.  Gary Oldman (Tinker Tailor ...) plays the scientist/inventor with some morals and Michael Keaton (Batman) plays a moral-free corporate suit who together decide what to make and/or do with Robocop.  Abbie Cornish (Bright Star) is wasted as a grieving wife and Jennifer Ehle (Sunshine) is a thankless corporate gopher -- the female characters are weak here.  It appears to want to stir-up some damning debate but it fails as the one making the colorful political commentary -- Samuel L. Jackson -- has too much fun with his small, wholly unnecessary role.  Inserting him into the film a time or two doesn't "work".  The film should have "gone there" ... but it never does.

Despite still being able to appreciate the gritty and gruesome quality of the original, rebooting 'RoboCop' was understandable given the film technology we have now. I got to admit, I was quite half-impressed with the trailers. However, I would't have supported it if I knew they were going to turn it into RoboCrap. 

First of all, the event leading up to the cop's near fatal injuries pales in comparison to the original. A car explosion at his house just seemed like a quick and lazy way for the writers to get him into the robo-suit as soon as possible without establishing much foundation for the viewer to feel empathy towards him and his family. There is also problems with logic in some parts of the film. One example being when robocop catches a wanted murderer and rapist at his promotional event. Show me a wanted criminal who would turn up at an event littered with police officers, let a alone a state of the art robocop, and I'll show you a situation which is unrealistically dumb and takes the audience for mugs. I didn't like the whole idea where robocop malfunctioned from being too emotional. It represented a very feeble way of building tension in a scene. Getting too emotional may have impact at a little tea party but not in an action movie setting. 

One of the main flaws concerns the story's focus on the corporation's attempts to market robocop. It was a necessary part of the plot since it demonstrated how he was treated more as a product than a human being but this took too much precedence over seeing robocop kick some criminal butt. Apart from the training simulation scenes, there was not a lot of seeing robocop in action. The ending sequences were okay in displaying glimpses of robocop's combat skills but this mainly served to show what was substantially missing from earlier parts of the movie. Back in 1987 Robocop was an instant hit. No surprise there as the franchise was clearly a new concept and the era was bringing some good action movies one after the other and Robocop was riding the new wave. After 27 years the half man half mech robot is rebooted and it certainly looks good. Though plot is slightly similar to the original since the new Robocop has vast differences to its presentation my intention here is not to compare the two movies but to concentrate on the new version.

The movie background runs in 2028. American drone and robot technology has evolved in to a stage where their wars off shore are largely handled by unmanned machines. Yet the domestic situation remains hostile to the machines and Omnicorp the large corporate responsible for building the robots are looking for ways to enter the local market. And they find their ticket when Alex Murphy a detective in the police department gets injured in the line of duty. Omnicorp transforms Alex in to a half man half machine Robocop with wrong intentions and Alex starts to disobey his programs letting his human side to take control.

At a glance it's evident that the CG work done here is outstanding. Not like in the 80s now the industry is well equipped to make Robocop visually beautiful without using much of onset props. Therefore the man in machine looks flawless and the technology looks spick and span. And when the action kicks in it really blasts. Yet what makes the true contribution to the new Robocop is not how it looks but how it feels. The director spends a great deal of time (Almost exactly half of the runtime) conceptualizing and building the background to bring in the hybrid. The viewer gets a full picture of the political situation against the movement and the corporate strategy that goes in to building the Robocop. And giving a solid foundation the story of Alex Murphy is well put and it's emotional. Though the entire movie is highly predictable there is joys in seeing things unveil.

So way back in...whenever, we were given the news of a remake for the ultra violent uber satirical comicbook styled sci-fi 'Robocop', directed by Arsene Wenger, wait what?! One hoped twas a poor joke but unfortunately as you all know it wasn't, so here we are now...'I wouldn't buy that for a dollar' hehe...no seriously its a line in the film.

After an intro the film kicks off and we get the classic Basil Poledouris theme stomping its way over the opening credits...sweet. Well not really because the theme has been tampered with and sounds completely off key and fudging awful, strike one Robocop reboot. 

The plot is generally along the same lines as classic Robo (that's how I will refer to the original, classic Robo) with Murphy being struck down by some bad guys and coming back from the brink of death as a robotic police officer. All this admist a corrupt police force helped along by the dark OmniCorp company which provides advanced robots for the US military. The original film had a biting satirical edge influenced by a Reagan era of heavy consumer culture, privatisation, capitalism and greed, a truly slimy corporate climate full of greasy suits. So what does this film have you ask? how can this film hope to create such a sharp edge when classic Robo's plot no longer fits the bill. 

Well this film firmly goes down the sort of relative notion of our current climate, asking if robots with guns (or robots at all) should be allowed to roam around controlling human beings (replacing the police mainly). Is it right to have a mechanical object with artificial intelligence in charge of pulling the trigger and possibly terminating a human life, plus of course the subject of national security is ever present. The film starts off overseas as robots/drones patrol the streets of Tehran, a display of American power and might over a much poorer simple people. Naturally and predictably we are shown straight away how a powerful robot (ED-209) can cut down an innocent child who was wielding a simple knife. So the modern day debate surrounding drones being used abroad to replace troops is stuffed in your face well and truly. The debate about drones policing us on a regular basis is still very much science fiction and could be shoved in any action film.

Although the use of these themes are well presented it still doesn't really feel overly relevant to today's society. The distinct lack of any real dark humour or dark satire on social commentary through any media is really obvious, this was the fabric of the original film and half the reason it was so good (other half was uber violence). Other smaller issues pop up which again seem to be by-products of films these days. Why is the character of Lewis now a black man? I'm not saying that's wrong but why the need to change that character? is that a PC move? wouldn't a female character create more emotion in a crisis? I realise this film wants to distance itself from the original but changes like this just seem utterly pointless, change for changes sake, there are other important issues to think about. Plus a strong female character works well usually and can be a plus for a film. In fact the whole point of that character seems completely defunct now anyway seeing as he does nothing to aid the new plot, reduced to a background character.

As for Robo himself and the crux of the film, well its a mixed bag really. While the action sequences are very slick and lovely to look at (unsurprisingly) they do come across as any old first person shooter for your Xbox (or Playstation if you're that way inclined). Yes I know it sounds cliche me saying this but I have to because that's what those sequences look like, the infrared shoot out especially with all those colourful cross hairs and readouts popping up everywhere. Robo's HUD in general, while looking very pretty, seemed way too over the top for me. I realise the tech is suppose to be white hot but really? Robo can even tell what emotion a person is going through or about to go through...WARNING: VIOLENCE IMMINENT: THREAT, SUBJECT COOPERATIVE: NON THREAT. Soooo can Robo tell if a piss or sneeze is imminent too? Then you got all that crap going on when he's scanning around as if he can see through everything and project perfect virtual isometric 3D images with measurements and angles etc...come on! all that makes him too powerful, the HUD can do anything!

Its too easy for Robo in this film, he can pinpoint criminals within 10 minutes with his super HUD, no human can make a move in this city without him knowing and sniffing you out sheesh! Anyway this leads me to the suit, the famous suit, is it better than classic Robo? don't be ridiculous. Now I'll admit it looks better in silver trim of course, we all know that, but that doesn't save it. Overall it still looks plastic to me, close up or from a distance...still looks plastic I'm afraid with no real weight to it either. Its like any modern day piece of electronic equipment really, plastic with pointless LED lights on it. Kinnaman's face is too normal looking if you ask me, wouldn't there be any damage burns or scars?? He doesn't move like a robot either, he just walks around and moves as normal with badly added sound effects that don't sync up. Also he doesn't seem to have any speech issues or twitches or anything, surely you'd have some visual signs of mental stress...apart from crying and grimacing. In short this guy takes to being a head in a jar in a robot very easily frankly, no sweat. 

Overall it looks like what we all thought with the release of the first images online, a man in a plastic ripped ninja suit. Of course the human hand doesn't help one bit, I appreciate the idea behind it but no. Its not totally dreadful, his helmet and visor are quite cool with the red Cylon thing going on. What I don't get is the need to give his cheesy 'Knight Rider' rip off bike (it does look bloody awful and babyish, Batbike anyone?) those two daft looking red visor-like slits too, thinking of toy merchandise sales there methinks. One thing I thought of during the infrared shootout was the fact that his red helmet visor kinda gave his position away in the dark didn't it, like a target for his head...shoot me here.

The action sequences are impressive effects wise but that's no big deal these days. Sure ED-209 looks OK and sounds OK but really so what? that's only a small cog in a big wheel, this film could of been so much more. The action hints at being really solid had it been for ADULTS! yes I'm sorry but that's the bottom line. There were some nice moments but they fizzled out under a PG-13 rating which wouldn't allow them to be truly kickass. The only one sequence which comes close to a true adult Robocop moment is when we see Murphy taken apart revealing just a head, throat and lungs. There's also another small moment when we see 'Norton' operating on Murphy's brain...but that's it, that's all we get.

Other than that its really weak in places and really tries too hard...just like Kinnaman who does his best tough guy act at the start which is awful. His Robo effort isn't much better really seeing as he still comes across exactly the same as before he was blown up. There aren't any bad guys in the film either really, think about it, there isn't really  any actual nasty bad guy you really wanna see killed off. Sellars doesn't really feel or act like a bad guy, like Novak he actually brings good arguments to the table about using robots in the US for security, saving more lives overall. 

Mattox is more of an annoying employee than a bad guy, just slap him, stop being so robophobic against that poor robot fella. The main crime boss and his henchmen are so flippin' weak its untrue, they're barely naughty let alone vicious drug dealers, they don't do anything! On the tiny plus side I did quite like how they tweaked Robo's brain so he could perform better because his human side was causing hesitation (no memory wipes in the future?). Just a shame they spoiled that by having him miraculously override further brain programming by...beats me! the power of love?

Oh and how on earth was there CCTV footage of Murphy's murder? it was on his driveway, what there is a CCTV pointing at his driveway from the street? he has his own CCTV? oh he did it seems, handy.

Its been said before and I will say it again, the film admittedly isn't the car crash I thought it would be, it is a well made sci-fi visually...but its no Robocop film. Had this been a stand alone sci-fi I could look on it more favourably despite similarities. End of the day it still remains a toothless sanitsed, factory production line CGI offering that will be forgotten about within months. The least said about the end credits music track choice the better and at least Jackson got to use his favourite curse words at the very end huh guess that will please the masses (facepalm).

Originally released in 1987, RoboCop has garnered a huge fan base and the reboot was eagerly anticipated by both the old guard of 80's action fans and a new generation of movie goers. So Padilha has his task cut out for him, could he satisfy both factions?
Unfortunately the answer is no and it would be surprising if either group were satisfied with the finished product. It seems like yet another case of the-man-behind-the-curtain syndrome, most notably in the decision to aim for a PG13 rating, against Padilha's wishes, in order to ensure a film that went severely over budget recoups some of its investment. I agree that graphic violence is not necessary in order to make a good action movie, just look at The Dark Knight or Star Trek, but RoboCop falls short of the mark here and delivers a very placid final product. It can be argued that's what happens when the creative control is limited but perhaps hiring a director who's previous work is rated 18+ was the greater mistake.
The cast however is strong and Kinnaman(The Killing) executes his role efficiently, with support from veteran actors Oldman, Keaton and Jackson but even this solid foundation seemed somewhat hollow. In a throwback to the satirical nature, that flowed seamlessly throughout the original, Jackson's portrayal of the rhetoric spewing media mogul appears a little disjointed and does little to add to an already inferior reboot.
In total RoboCop 2014 does its best to recreate a character that criminals of Detroit should fear but in the end only offers us a modern day Tin-Man and by the closing credits I could not help but think, 'I wouldn't buy that for a dollar'.

It was 12:00 midnight on April 4th, 2014, ladies and gentlemen, when I finally decided I was officially done with Hollywood. I watched the Robocop remake last night, and I don't think I've ever been this depressed about the future of cinema in general in my entire life. Not because the film is really one of the worst movies of all time (it's not), but because of the pure and unfettered irony and complete ignorance of the art of filmmaking it takes to make a movie like this one. Making a mainstream blockbuster adaptation of Robocop is like making a TV show out of The Truman Show, or a theme park out of Jurassic Park. It misses the point of the original creation in a way that only money-grubbing Hollywood buttholes could. God, what a depressing turn of events.

The original Robocop is without a doubt one of my all-time favorite movies. Don't laugh, it's true. Although elitist cinema snobs (Cutler) will undoubtedly turn their noses up at Robocop because of its excessive gore and pew pew pews, it's actually far deeper than most people give it credit for. Under the surface of that remarkable film is a startlingly well-thought-out political allegory about America's culture of vapidity and the state of our culture. It is truly the rarest breed of film: Intelligent trash. So how ironic is it that this film that debases the warped, violent culture of America has now been transformed into a film that represents everything WRONG with the warped, violent culture of America? It would probably be funny if it weren't so damn depressing. Not only did the filmmakers totally miss the point of Robocop, but they did all they could to absolutely destroy my enjoyment of the original film. That's the worst kind of sequel, prequel, or remake-the one that prevents you from ever watching the original movie again without your perception of it sullied.

My biggest problem with this film is, as you may have guessed, the blatant commercialization and dumbing down of the source material. Right from the get-go, it's painfully obvious that this film is nothing more than a cynical attempt to turn a sarcastic and sardonic movie into a mainstream Hollywood blockbuster. The original film is practically a parody of the action genre, but this movie ignores those roots and peppers the runtime with unnecessary action sequences, explosions, and militaristically clichéd speeches by Samuel L. Jackson. It's every bit as empty-headed, generic, and silly as the movies that the original Robocop so expertly skewered. Sure, the original had its fair share of gore and violence (in fact, it had to be censored just to retain an R rating), but at least it served the story. The subversive wit and social commentary of it more than makes up for any detours it may have made into generic blockbuster territory. It's not perfect, but it was certainly a lot better than this load of manure.

The performances, as one would expect, are nothing special in the slightest. Joel Kinniman is bland and uninteresting as Robocop himself, giving us very little to root for in the hero. Sure, he's a cyborg... that doesn't mean he can't be an interesting character. Samuel L. Jackson plays the angry black guy again, and Gary Oldman (as always) is the best part, although his character is a stereotypical scientist in the vein of Kiefer Sutherland in Dark City. It would be really interesting to one day have a scientist character in a film who isn't a wimpy, geeky butthole, but apparently scriptwriters these days are more devoted to tropes than ever. I think I can safely say that most of the actors do the best with what they're given, but what they're given isn't much-The story is overcomplicated, the script is generic and dull, and the whole film lacks any of the energy that was put into the action sequences and CGI. 

Final Score for Robocop: 2/10 stars. Yeah, this thing is awful. To be fair, this movie is only bad enough to merit maybe a 3 or a 4, but because it so tragically and hilariously missed the point of the original movie, I can't help but hate it. If you want a textbook example of why Hollywood these days is terrible, look no further than Robocop. Otherwise, there is no reason to sit through this lifeless, emotionless, painfully ironic piece of Hollywood drivel. Everything about this movie is by-the-numbers, generic, and headache-inducing, from its lame dialogue to its incoherent action sequences. If you're a fan of the original, definitely stay away. If you're an idiot like Jed who likes remakes more than original films, check it out. All I can say is one thing: It's even dumber than the things that the original made fun of.

The tone of this film is the major reason as to the criticism of this film; even before it was released in theaters. Back in the day (1980s-1990s) films could've been campy and cool. We've had plenty of dark films with some camp elements. Now in the post 9-11 era, films have taken themselves too seriously. Gone are the fun campy elements in big action films. A prime example would be the Bond/Batman films compared to today. Even though I enjoy both interpretations. I do admit there were some campy elements to the Batman films of the 80s-90s. Obviously, the Roger Moore, Pierce Brosnan and even Timothy Dalton films had some campy elements in their Bond films. The gradual shift into the post years after Sept. 11 called for a more serious tone, the threat and suspense of these films were heightened and the villain and protagonist became more ruthless. However these films are void of the humor that lightens the tone. 9-11 is not just a reason for the absence of campiness, it's because the audiences has changed. I'm pretty sure if there was a campy moment in one of Daniel Craig's bond film or Nolan's Batman, the tone of the film would feel unbalanced.
Robocop is a hard film to remake. The sadistic characters like Clarence Boddiker, the action sequences, claymation animation, satirical look at society, hyped up violence, over use of blood squibs and one liners. Even though this film was really violent and the characters were fuckin nuts, you could still laugh at the film because of the tone. Robocop is not a film to be taken seriously, it is a film that is suppose to entertain you for two hours. Gone are the fun, sadistic characters (I did like Jackie Earle Haley's character), claymation (obviously), blood squibs and overuse of violence. The film has a somewhat satirical look at society at how much heavy influence political affiliation has on society. Throughout the film, congress is trying to enact a law that will allow robots to work in law enforcement. Samuel L. Jackson plays a hybrid of Glenn Beck, Bill o'Reilly, mixed with Al Sharpton's hair and I would also say his character gets real passionate on topics like Rachel Maddow. I felt that Jackson character is a satire on how political pundits who have a heavy influence on the choices people make. 
The other actors were okay, the guy who plays Robocop was forgettable. Then again...so was the original actor. I know it may offend people when I say the original actor didn't have any gravitas to the first Robocop, but ask yourself this question: What could you say about the Murphy before he was Robocop? What was the most interesting thing about Murphy before he was killed and then revived as Robocop? I do admit the other actor did convey more of a human element to the film. We have some character build up in the film during the pre-Robocop scenes. This film deals with the conflict of human vs. machine, so there are moments when the character will override the system due to his emotions or free will. The action sequences are nothing spectacular. This film is pretty straight-forward. What I enjoyed about the original film was the sequence of Robocop responding to crimes that had no connection to the plot. There are no scenes of Robocop saving hostages from a crazy politician, preventing a convenient store robbery by killing the robbers/causing a lot of property damage and who could forget, apprehending a rapist after shooting his dick off. The remake doesn't provide us any of that action instead it goes directly to concluding the plot. That's the problem, the film doesn't give any time to have fun and explore Robocop. I realized this was a major issue when I enjoyed the training sequence in this film. This is a part of the film where you get to see what Robocop can do, even the exposition of how the machine works with Murphy was wonderfully done. Even though the training sequence and other action sequences felt like a videogame, it was the best part of the movie. Another thing that is missing from this film is the atmosphere.
It's ironic that now would be the perfect time to create Robocop. The first film did predict the economic and social decline of Detroit. It is still considered to be one of the dangerous cities in the US. Technology is on the cusp of creating a machine like Robocop. However this remake failed to capture the atmosphere of a crime ridden city. Detroit actually looks clean and, not deserted. The first film really captured Detroit as a city that has literally become Hell. There is nothing in the remake that'll make you think Detroit is dangerous.
Growing up in the 90's, parents weren't as PC or overly protected as they are now. I, like many kids grew up watching violent films like Robocop and the Terminator films. Hell, they had toys and a Saturday morning cartoon of Robocop. So I'm pretty sure companies were aware that kids were watching these violent R rated films. Now we've made a shift into PG-13 since most movies have grossed the most under the rating. There are certain films that can be done with a lower rating, however films like Robocop cannot. The violence that almost gave this film an X rating is what gives Robocop it's charm. Without all of the elements that were previously mentioned, this is just some generic sci/fi action film. Wait for this film to be in your 7.99 DVD bin at Wal-Mart.

It is impossible for the new "RoboCop" film to avoid comparison to the 1987 original version, particularly for die-hard fans prepared to analyze the reboot with scrutiny and a sense of disillusionment for recreating a sci-fi classic. It has been years since I've watched the original "RoboCop," and while some of its most iconic quotes and satirical themes still resonate with me, I made it a point to avoid re-watching the original film as I do when preparing for any remake or book adaptation. By experience, a re-watch or re-read will result in angry outbursts at the theater for minor dialog or plot changes, creating an insufferable experience for myself and anyone sitting near me. Of course, if you've never seen the original "RoboCop," you have nothing to worry about.

Surprisingly enough, "RoboCop" launches with the promise that it is, in fact, more in-tune with our present day political issues, or rather, the political issues we will be facing in the year 2028. We are immediately greeted by the strongly opinionated television news anchor Pat Novak, played with feverous entitlement by Samuel L. Jackson as he channels his inner Fox News reporter. Novak discusses the "robo-phobic" mentality of American robotic forces being used for military purposes, primarily in Tehran, where suicide-bombers sacrifice their lives to destroy the massive, war-prevention machines. Unfortunately, this irony goes largely unnoticed, along with the numerous chances "RoboCop" has to pose any effective political statements. The film becomes all too concerned with OmniCorp, a multinational corporation striving for the distribution of robotic soldiers for war, and ultimately, as law enforcement agents. The problem, however, is that Americans do not trust artificially intelligent forces due to their lack of human cognition and emotional responsiveness.

Right on cue, we are introduced to Alex Murphy, a police detective who is violently killed in a car bomb explosion. Alex suffers severe burns on over 80% of his body and loses practically all of his limbs, making him OmniCorp's best suitor for the half-human, half-machine they dreamed of creating for public support. Alex's heart, lungs, and damaged brain are all that remain, displayed with gory yet beautiful detail in glass encasings. He is kept alive artificially within his black steel armor, and his brain chemistry is altered to react more like a machine than an emotional human. He is merely an illusion of depth, much like the remainder of the film, which relies entirely on explosive mayhem and an overly complex plot to hold the attention of its viewers.

Eventually, "RoboCop" manages to find the man inside the machine, attempting to convince us that there were affirmations of heart and humanity all along the way. This attempt is ultimately futile, because "RoboCop" is more concerned with guns and explosions than it is with human cognition, corporate greed, or political satire-something the original film did with imaginative perfection. By all accounts, the "Robocop" reboot is a largely entertaining film filled with action-packed sequences and spectacular CGI. It simply plays out too generically to leave a lasting impression.

Not everything that we could have gained from the use of filmmaking technology, but not at all a worthless effort overall. The downside is that it did nothing to improve the overall storyline, nor did it really bring anything new to the picture other than a few visual upgrades and a little bit of humanity. Humanity in the sense that Robocop acted more like a normal street cop than his predecessor, Peter Weller. Still, the action scenes and the toned down violence did little more than rile us up with no real sense of gain in the movie itself. It felt like Robocop's greatest achievement was when he shot the rapist/murderer in the middle of the crowd. Beyond that, the other things he did seemed as simple as tracing some phone calls and running into a building, guns blazing. This was done way better in the original. 

Still, as said before, it was not a complete loss. Although the partnership of Officer Lewis was one of the high points of the first one, his new partner, Officer Lewis (haha, funny) was more toned down, but still had a good effect all around. The chemistry between the two was not as effective in this remake, and taking it out of the spotlight was a decent move. 

We did get to see more of Robocop, but his presence was much less menacing, and he was much sleeker. This also leads to the downfall that never get to see him take down a simple gas station robbery, nor does he take down any smaller crimes other than ones pertaining to the head crime boss. The real problem with this is that we never see him interact with the common people of the city. There was no "Have a nice day" or "Stay safe, citizen." We only get a grand scope of his deeds and no real look at how he deals with your normal, everyday crime.

The last thing of note is that there was a gigantic sideplot of his wife and son, where it was overlooked a lot more in the original. Whether this is a good thing or a bad thing is up to individual opinion, but it also means that we see a lot less of Robocop enforcing the law, and a lot less of the overall plot itself. It was a trade off, but was it truly worth it? I'd say no. 

A mediocre reboot, overall, but it is worth watching if you're in the mood for an action flick where a little thinking is in order.

MY REVIEW OF ROBOCOP (1 Star)

Remakes don't tend to excite, especially when the original was just fine on its own.  A do-over on a terrible film is another story, but I have to admit to being a little excited when I heard Jose Padilha was directing the remake of Paul Verhoeven's 1987 classic.  Padilha, a Brazilian filmmaker, impressed me greatly with his ELITE SQUAD movies, filled as they were with visceral, impactful action.  Additionally, THE KILLING's Joel Kinnaman would be slipping into the lead role, and I have found him to be a powerful, hugely empathetic presence.  

It was obvious to me that the reboot would make the original look clunky when looking at the huge leaps and bounds we've seen in effects work, and that is very much the case here.  I can also appreciate that the remake is going for an entirely different tone.  Whereas the 1987version was a sly, humorous and satirical look at corporate greed and BIG BROTHER politics, the remake plays it straight as a largely serious explosion of action.  As such, it's a flat, boring, painfully repetitive exercise in boom-bang-kapow.

Initially, I thought there was promise as Samuel L. Jackson is a pundit/reporter who frames the film with his SNAKES ON A PLANE/DEEP BLUE SEA speechifying.  His reporting leads us to an effective sequence in Tehran in which we're introduced to OmniCorp's experimental robot police state.  Reminiscent of DISTRICT 9, I thought we were in for a fresh spin on totalitarianism.  The intelligence pretty much ends here.

Cue Kinnaman as Alex Murphy, a cop who is nearly decimated in an attack.  Looking to launch their robots in the U.S., OmniCorp identifies Murphy as a prime candidate - happy husband/father, all American, yadda yadda.  The aftermath of said attack is brutal and provides for some memorable imagery.  For a second there, I really felt for Murphy's plight.  What follows, however, for the remainder of the film is our title character cycling around and shooting people...nonstop.  THE END.  It's a numbing experience.  There's nothing left to say about it.  See the original and ELITE SQUAD: THE ENEMY WITHIN and you'll thank me later.

With the slew of remakes and reboots flooding the gates of Hollywood these days you wouldn't really be surprised to see anything get that kind of treatment. Usually when it does the first question asked tends to be "do we really need another (insert movie here)"? I can happily say with José Padilha's reboot of Robocop that the answer is a big fat yes!

Padilha alters certain elements of the 1980's cult classic (and probably to the dismay of a lot of die hard fans) like Robo's partner is now an African American male, they change his origin story as well. The changing of the partner was a minor difference in the grand scheme of things, and the changing of Robocop's origin fit better with the overall theme of the movie.

Where as Robocop in the 80's featured themes about the media, gentrification, corruption, authoritarianism, greed, privatization, capitalism, identity, dystopia, and human nature. The 2014 remake covers a lot of the same ground and in fact has even more meaning today as many of those thematic elements still exist of have worsened since 1987. Furthermore Padhilha's remake touches on drone attacks, removing the human element from work, and privacy (all of which are very hot topics).

So Robocop has the themes locked down. How does it play as a film? To my surprise it easily surpassed the bar I had set for it. Originally this movie was not pre-screened for critics which is usually a bad sign about how well it will be received. But after it's conclusion I found myself excited and eagerly awaiting a sequel (something that the ending leaves plenty of room for).

While it isn't a gory as the original this new incarnation of Robocop packed in a ton of great action scenes, and while it shied away from being overly gory it certainly wasn't your standard "PG Style" action. From a cinematic standpoint everything looked great. The visuals looked solid throughout.

What really hooked me was how much Joel Kinnaman brought to the role of Alex Murphy/Robocop. As Robocop he certainly channeled Peter Weller at times but brought his own thing to it. In fact I feel like he added more humanity to the character and even maybe deepened it a bit more.   I was truly caught off guard how real he made such a ridiculous character seem, he took what could have been some really awful scenes and totally made them work.

Michael Keaton   also gets a ton of credit as Raymond Sellers the big bad guy in the film. Keaton really manages to walk the line of "he's a bad guy, but I can kind of see where he is coming from" and those types of villains are the best villains in the world. As the movie draws to a close there are a few moments though where he starts twirling his mustache a little bit too much.

Gary Oldman and Sam Jackson in secondary roles are both pretty darn solid throughout the movie as the voices for using Robocop to his fullest potential and for remembering that he is still a human being and should be treated as such.

Even though there are some flaws that might be worth quibbling over the ultimate result is a movie with a relevant message while still being a fantastic science fiction action movie with lots of PEW! PEW! and BANG! BANG! but it is also well made, and obviously with some love for the original.  Given that you have no choice in whether this film would get made.......what more could you ask for?

Oh and hardcore Robo fans....... Don't worry to much about that black suit Alex Murphy dawns for the majority of the flick...... Let's just say it doesn't make until the end credits.

It is impossible for the new "RoboCop" film to avoid comparison to the 1987 original version, particularly for die-hard fans prepared to analyze the reboot with scrutiny and a sense of disillusionment for recreating a sci-fi classic. It has been years since I've watched the original "RoboCop," and while some of its most iconic quotes and satirical themes still resonate with me, I made it a point to avoid re-watching the original film as I do when preparing for any remake or book adaptation. By experience, a re-watch or re-read will result in angry outbursts at the theater for minor dialog or plot changes, creating an insufferable experience for myself and anyone sitting near me. Of course, if you've never seen the original "RoboCop," you have nothing to worry about.

	Surprisingly enough, "RoboCop" launches with the promise that it is, in fact, more in-tune with our present day political issues, or rather, the political issues we will be facing in the year 2028. We are immediately greeted by the strongly opinionated television news anchor Pat Novak, played with feverous entitlement by Samuel L. Jackson as he channels his inner Fox News reporter. Novak discusses the "robo-phobic" mentality of American robotic forces being used for military purposes, primarily in Tehran, where suicide-bombers sacrifice their lives to destroy the massive, war-prevention machines. Unfortunately, this irony goes largely unnoticed, along with the numerous chances "RoboCop" has to pose any effective political statements. The film becomes all too concerned with OmniCorp, a multinational corporation striving for the distribution of robotic soldiers for war, and ultimately, as law enforcement agents. The problem, however, is that Americans do not trust artificially intelligent forces due to their lack of human cognition and emotional responsiveness.

Right on cue, we are introduced to Alex Murphy, a police detective who is violently killed in a car bomb explosion. Alex suffers severe burns on over 80% of his body and loses practically all of his limbs, making him OmniCorp's best suitor for the half-human, half-machine they dreamed of creating for public support. Alex's heart, lungs, and damaged brain are all that remain, displayed with gory yet beautiful detail in glass encasings. He is kept alive artificially within his black steel armor, and his brain chemistry is altered to react more like a machine than an emotional human. He is merely an illusion of depth, much like the remainder of the film, which relies entirely on explosive mayhem and an overly complex plot to hold the attention of its viewers.

Eventually, "RoboCop" manages to find the man inside the machine, attempting to convince us that there were affirmations of heart and humanity all along the way. This attempt is ultimately futile, because "RoboCop" is more concerned with guns and explosions than it is with human cognition, corporate greed, or political satire-something the original film did with imaginative perfection. By all accounts, the "Robocop" reboot is a largely entertaining film filled with action-packed sequences and spectacular CGI. It simply plays out too generically to leave a lasting impression.

Jackson shouting at the camera about why America is so robophobic, leading huge conglomerate Omnicorp to build a half man half machine that the Americans can rally behind. When dedicated cop Alex Murphy is caught in a deadly car explosion, Omnicorp jump in and fuse his remaining working organs to a metal machine. For a 12A rating, the moment you see what is left of Alex is startling and hard to watch, that scene is definitely a 15 rated moment. I loved the huge cast, it's like a dream assemble for me, no one gets underused and I loved the dialogue and interactions between Michael Keaton, Jennifer Ehle and Jay Baruchel, they were very well performed and written. Robocop 2014 is a good movie if you watch it with an open mind. THe original Robocop was a masterpiece, a time capsule of the 80s and a perfect product of its time and place. This reboot does not attempt to do what the original did. It is a far different animal but it is not a bad one. If the original spoofed consumer culture in the 80s laying on a thick lather of sarcasm and gore this more modest PG 13 rated version tries to ensconce our modern day consumer and media culture: focus groups, marketing, globalized production and the ever-present camera and cellphone. 

Acting wise the movie is a no starter. Samuel L. Jackson plays out of type and does it horribly, Gary Oldman and Michael Keaton chew up the scenery one as a tormented scientist, the other as a Ballmer meets Jobs no-holds-barred businessman and MK Williams and Jackie Earle Haley are under if not straight mis-used. Kinnaman does a decent job as a more family-focused Alex Murphy but he is unfit for the role any way you put it. The directing is competent but not outstanding, and while the concept and story aren't bad and manage to deliver within the constraints of the  PG13 rating one cannot help but think what robocop could have been with some decent practical effects and more worldbuilding. 

Tl;Dr Watch Robocop with an open mind and it is an enjoyable if bland action movie. Compare it to the flawless 1980s version and you're going to have a bad time.

"Robocop" 10 Scale Rating: 8.0 (Great) ...

The Good: Way WAY better than I expected. A great mix of sci-fi and action that more than holds up against the original. While Kinnaman was a little too stiff early on, he gets much better as the film progresses. Heavyweights Micheal Keaton, Gary Oldman, and Samuel L. Jackson turn in great performances as the cast did a good job all around. A very pleasant surprise early in 2014.

The Bad: A little overly cynical at times. I was fine with it being dark, but sometimes it was a little much. Eventually, Robocop overcomes his programming with no explanation. They hint that it might be his "human soul" at work, but that just seemed a little too convenient and silly.

Gone is the gore, harcore violence and R-rated bad language; replaced is a film you'd be safe to take your kids to. While many of the famous quips remain, giving fans a referential comparison point, there really wouldn't be much similar with Verhoven's classic b-grade action-exploitation flick. Director Padilha's Robocop has much more of a video game aesthetic, with its FPS action set pieces and familiar punchy chase sequences. It doesn't leave the genre wheelhouse too often, which makes for a somewhat predictable, but solidly entertaining, film, with great leading man in Kinnaman and supports from Oldman and Keaton.

Lovingly nicknamed Rob 'O Cop, this updated retelling of the Irish robot cop Alex Murphy is one of the better remakes I've seen. As with any remake expectations must be tempered even with a cast as alluring as this has. Even with a PG-13 rating, director Jose Padilha manages to turn in a decent action filled new take of the ultra violent 1987 cult classic of the same name.

Obviously we shouldn't be expecting any Oscar nods here for acting but the cast is solid and delivers more than you would expect. I've yet to see Joel Kinnaman in anything else but I'm pleased with his performance as the title character. Samuel L. Jackson continues to do his thing and is always good for a laugh but for me Gary Oldman really gives you more than you ask for with a movie of this nature.

As is the case with any remake you're going to have plenty in the "hate it" camp, it all depends on how you feel about the original and what you expect with this version. The story lines are pretty much the same but are told differently enough that this version can stand on its own in my opinion. The special effects are top notch and the action is exciting as well as engrossing. I also enjoyed this version taking on more of a human side and psychological view on what happens when you mix man and machine.

Fans of the original can expect to hear some of their favorite lines in this version which I thought was a nice touch and had hoped to hear them. The film doesn't try to do too much, yet it delivers more than just an action movie. It strikes that tricky balance of being more than you would expect but not trying too hard.

In the end I would recommend Robocop to fans of the original, action junkies, and average popcorn flick viewers. Please remember though, don't set your expectations too high, no remake should ever have high expectations. I went into this movie with the mindset of "this looks decent, the cast is awesome, it certainly has the potential to be good but it will probably just be a good action movie", I advise you to adopt the same and you'll be pleasantly surprised with what you find.

If there's one thing the internet has turned to hating besides the Star Wars prequels and Twilight, it's remakes. No one wanted RoboCop to be remade as it is considered a classic action sci-fi that wasn't afraid to add some raunchiness. But there is more that meets the eye to this particular remake.

In the original film, Detective Murphy was never allowed any "humanity". The remake has more of a focus on the side of Murphy's family. It's practically a different situation. In this RoboCop world, the ED-209s and other machines have already been distributed to other countries, but are banned in the US. And countries like Iraq are sending out suicide bombers to tell the world how bad it is, only to be covered up with what must be Samuel L. Jackson's parody of Bill O'Reilly.

Acting in this film is pretty much summed up with Gary Oldman as Dr. Dennett Norton and Samuel L. Jackson as the heavily biased Pat Novak. They had solid performances, and the rest of the cast was okay. Nothing to brag about. Joel Kinnaman plays a good RoboCop, not so much Murphy. Abbie Cornish, who plays Murphy's wife Carla, has proven her ability to cry on command, as she does throughout the movie. Michael Keaton always made a great bad guy to me, he and Jay Baruchel make the meeting scenes interesting

The plot is significantly altered from it's original, as it involves the family of Murphy, and it has more substance to it. There's more to it than just revenge. Murphy isn't a mannequin put into a robotic suit, he's a head with organs, and one hand. He's struggling emotionally and physically, and I will say I cared more about this protagonist than the one from the original film. Also, Michael K. Williams plays a charismatic partner while the original Nancy Allen seems less likable.

Even the motives for creating RoboCop are different, besides the common factor of money. The aspect of American politics added in makes it more interesting, and the question of free will is a refreshingly deeper question for the audience.

Action was a bit less impressive than you'd expect. You get to see RoboCop arrest or shoot a lot of people, but it is fairly repetitive in how he does it. Nothing will ever compare to the 1987 RoboCop bold choices in both blood spurts and dark scenarios. As far as PG-13 goes, it's perfectly acceptable, but we all wanted a rated R RoboCop.

Besides the redesigning of the costume, the added plotlines, and some and a disappoint amount of blood, the remake isn't too far off from the original for me to give this a bad rating. Williams and Jackson give some of the best lines, while Kinnaman is stuck with the old catchphrases. It's a well paced, easily followed action film, that will definitely let you kill two hours.
